div.sent: The words Weather and Climate seem to be the same but the meanings are not the same.
The natural condition of a particular area of certain time of daily temperature, rain fall, storm, etc. of a particular area is called weather.
It is determined by measuring the temperature, humidity, rainfall, wind movement and pressure.
Weather may change daily or hourly and it actually does so.
On the other hand, the average weather of 30-40 years of an area is called climate.
But to know the climate of a country or region there are some important elements.
These are latitude, longitude, distance from sea, height from sea level, wind moment, ocean current, slope of land, soil structure and amount of forest.
As Bangladesh is located in tropical region, its climate is temperate.
That is to say, it is not very hot or not very cold here.
It is located near the sea.
The intensity of winter and summer is not severe due to the influence of monsoon.
Here winter season is dry and summer is warm and rainy.
Though the mountain Himalaya is not adjacent to the boundary of Bangladesh, it protects Bangladesh from Siberian snowfall.
For this reason winter season is not long here.
The temperature of Bangladesh remains 18-21 Celsius in winter.
Sometimes the temperature comes down to 4/5 Celsius in the north and south-eastern parts.
The intensity of winter is very high in Thakurgaon, Panchagor and Srimongal.
In Bangladesh summer begins from the month of Baishakh - it is mid April in English calendar.
Sometimes in summer the temperature goes up to 40/50 Celsius in the north and north-western parts of Bangladesh.
The Norwester occurs in some places in the beginning of monsoon.
Tornado and cyclone occur in the coastal areas.
In rainy season, the wind blows with water vapour from the south of the Bay of Bengal.
It is called the monsoon.
Heavy rainfall occurs in Bangladesh by the influence of monsoon.
Geographical Map of Bangladesh But the rainfall is not equal all over the country.
Excessive rainfall occurs in Sylhet, Chittagong, and Cox's Bazar.
On the other hand, less rainfall occurs in Rajshahi, Pabna and Kushtia.
Though rainfall occurs in Bangladesh in autumn, its quantity is very low.
River erosion increases in rainy season.
During April-May and October-November -these two times in a year cyclone and tidal wave occurs in Bangladesh.
The climate of Bangladesh is moderate.
It means the effects of favourable and adverse weather here is similar.
Because of favorable weather, the nature of Bangladesh is evergreen and ever fertile.
On the other hand, storm, tidal wave, flood, drought, norwester, tornado and excessive rainfall occur due to the influence of unfavorable weather.
These types of disaster bring miseries to the people of Bangladesh.
A long time ago a mammoth animal named Dinosaur lived in the world.
Nowadays nowhere this animal is found.
Sometimes the skeletons and bones of that extinct animal are found under the soil.
But why was this animal lost?
After research, scientists have found that 6.5 crore years ago the weather of the world became abnormal.
Its adverse impacts affected the landmass, water body, and the atmosphere of the world.
Finally, it affected the whole world.
For 20 lac years the change of weather continued.
This change over a long period of time affected the climate of the world.
Due to this change, the nature and environment were affected.
The cause of extinction of Dinosaur is this change of climate.
One of the causes of climate change of that time was frequent volcanic eruption.
Emitted gas, lava, ash, etc. from volcanic eruptions mixing with atmosphere made a barrier which kept the temperature of sunrays stuck in the earth.
For this reason temperature of the earth increased.
The gas responsible for increasing the temperature of the earth by making a barrier in the atmosphere is called the Green House Gas.
As a result, the sea level increased up to 200-300 feet high and the amount of landmass and forest area decreased.
Food scarcity for the animals arose.
Consequently, many animals including Dinosaur became extinct.
Even today, the main cause of climate change is the green house gas.
Carbondioxide, Methane, Nitrous oxide and Chloro-fluoro-carbon etc are combinedly called green house gas.
The spread of these gases excessively in the atmosphere increases the temperature of the earth.
Human activities are more responsible for the increase of the green house gas in the atmosphere.
The quantity of carbon dioxide is maximum among the green house gases created by men.
Carbon dioxide is produced from generating power, burning fuel of the vehicles, smoke and brick fields.
At present the quantity of transmitted green house gas has been increased by 80% to 90% than the previous.
From this, we can easily understand the adverse impacts of climate change.
The causes of climate change are almost the same in Bangladesh as in other regions of the world.
But like other developing countries, Bangladesh does not use as much fuel as the industrially developed countries do.
The temperature of the earth is increasing gradually for deforestation.
According to the opinion of the experts, a country needs about 25% forest of its total land area.
But in Bangladesh the amount of forest is only 16% of its total land area.
Moreover, the amount of forest is still decreasing because of indiscriminate cutting down of trees and destruction of hills and for some other reasons.
As a result of all these, the amount of rainfall in Bangladesh has also decreased.
Bangladesh is a disaster prone country.
Different types of disaster occur here.
Among them cyclone, tidal wave, river erosion, drought, cold wave, tornado, norwester etc are noteworthy.
Besides, Bangladesh has the risk of earthquake.
When the air of earth surface of a particular place gets hot, it blows upward.
As a result, air pressure of that place becomes less and air from other places rush to the low pressure areas.
This is called cyclone.
Most of the cyclones occur in Bangladesh due to the low pressure created by the Bay of Bengal.
This is called tidal wave.
Cyclones and tidal wave have struck the coastal area of Bangladesh several times severely and many people died and the cattle and crap were damaged.
On 12th November 1970, due to such a cyclone and tidal waves on the coastal region of Bangladesh, almost 10 lacs people died.
Sidr and Ailla were the two cyclones that occurred recently.
On 15th November, 2007, due to Sidr 30 lacs of people of 28 districts were badly affected.
And on 20th April, 2009 people, animals, crop and houses were severly damaged by Ailla.
Generally, weather forecast and warning messages are broadcast from the weather offices.
If we follow the alert and become careful, we can escape from the loss of lives.
To fight against disaster, we should take necessary preparations and take shelter in cyclone shelter centers and other safe places.
More or less, flood occurrs in Bangladesh almost every year.
Almost all the rivers of Bangladesh including the three main rivers - the Padma, the Meghna and the Jamuna are originated from India.
Thus flood occurs.
In this way, the capacity of containing water of the rivers decreases.
The water overflows and inundates the areas around the rivers.
Almost every year, flood damages our people and resources.
Crops are damaged hugely and consequently food crisis occars.
Many people become unemployed by losing their work.
In 1988, 1998, 2004 and 2007, massive flood occurred in our country.
Now the experts say, Flood cannot be stopped fully.
But we can minimize the losses due to flood.
River erosion is one of the regular disasters of Bangladesh.
It happens almost every year, especially in the rainy season.
One of the causes of river erosion is the nature of course of the rivers.
Most of the river courses are meandering.
Meanderingness of these rivers are frequent, consequently strong current cannot flow straight and strikes the banks and begins to erode the banks.
Due to river erosion thousand acres of cultivable land, residence and different constructions are being lost in the womb of the rivers.
As a result thousands of people of this country are becoming homeless and losing the opportunity of jobs, they are becoming destitute.
River erosion and its damages could be reduced if we are aware of the causes of river erosion and its effects.
Drought is a natural disaster of Bangladesh.
Drought occurs due to the lack of sufficient rainfall.
Almost every year at the end of spring and outset of summer draught occurs in the northern region of Bangladesh.
For the lack of water, irrigation is hampered, crops are damaged.
Besides lack of rainfall, drought also occurs for making dam in the upstream of many rivers, and for environment pollution.
Actually, it is not possible to prevent this natural disaster fully.
But if we are aware of it and take necessary steps in time, damages due to drought can be lessened.
For this, after examining ground water layer, lifting water from ground needs to be stopped.
In rainy season, we should reserve water.
The mass awareness about proper management and uses of water should be created.
Although Bangladesh is not a cold country mild and medium cold wind is noticed some years.
Especially in the northern region intensity of cold can be very high.
For extreme coldness many people die.
Cold wind makes human life miserable.
Ordinary people like day labourers and workers do not get work.
Cold wind damages crops.
The poor people fall in miserable conditions due to lack of houses and warm clothes.
Tornado is one of the mentionable natural disasters of Bangladesh.
This is an extremely speedy cyclone.
It is created by the low pressure in landmass.
Tornado is such a natural disaster about which no information could be predicted.
It can attack any place all on a sudden, and within few seconds, it can cause a massacre.
Its duration is very short few seconds to few minutes and very small area of a region is attacked by it.
Generally in Bangladesh, Tornado occurs from the beginning of Bengali month Falgun to the middle of Jaishthya, i.e. from mid-February to May.
Norwester is a kind of temporary and regionally created storm.
It is also called Kalbaishakhi in Bengali as it normally occurs in Bangla month Baishakh.
It often comes from the North-West direction.
In Bangladesh it occurs almost every year.
Though it is not as destructive as Tornado, it still does huge damage to common life.
It blows away houses, breaks away trees.
It disturbs the water-transport systems.
Many serious accidents occur due to Norwester.
So, precautions should be taken while moving in water-ways during Norwester season.
Among all the natural disasters, earthquake does the most damage in the shortest time.
Besides, no early warning can be given for earthquake.
Before anyone can come to understand anything, it turns the whole region into ruins through one or more jolts.
Mild, medium and huge earthquake may occur one after another in succession at a place simultaneously.
We have got this proof from the earthquakes that occurred in Iran, China, Mexico, Chile and Japan.
Bangladesh is also in danger zone of earthquake, especially Dhaka, Sylhet, Rangpur and Chittagong regions.
Mild earthquakes are occurring frequently in Chittagong and Sylhet.
The earthquake that occurred on 18 September, 2001 was quite strong.
Due to this, whole Bangladesh got a shake.
Till now men do not know how to prevent earthquakes.
But knowledge about safety, rescue and relief-work must be provided to common people.
If proper preparations can be taken before earthquake, loss of life can be reduced to a great extent.
